Package org.jtrim2.stream

Class AsyncProducerRef<T>

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.stream.AsyncProducerRef<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the produced elements
public final class AsyncProducerRef<T> extends Object
Defines an asynchronously populatable, but synchronously processed producer. That is, an asynchronously populatable sink which provides the source for the synchronous producers via a queue.

Note: Usually you want to create instances of this class via the factory methods in AsyncProducers.

Thread safety

Instances of this class can be shared by multiple threads safely, and its methods can be called concurrently.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:
  • AsyncProducers

  • Constructor Details

    • AsyncProducerRef

      public AsyncProducerRef(AsyncElementSink<T> elementSink, Supplier<SeqProducer<T>> producerFactory)
      Creates a new instance with the given asynchronously populatable sink providing the data for the given producers (created by the give factory).
      Parameters:
      elementSink - the asynchronously populatable sink providing the data for the synchronous producers. This argument will be returned as is by the getElementSink() method. This argument cannot be null.
      producerFactory - the factory creating producers providing the elements put into the sink. All producers share the same sink. This argument will be returned as is by the getProducerFactory() method. This argument cannot be null, and the factory may not return null.
      See Also:
      • AsyncProducers

  • Method Details

    • getElementSink

      public AsyncElementSink<T> getElementSink()
      Returns the asynchronously populatable sink providing the data for the synchronous producers.
      Returns:
      the asynchronously populatable sink providing the data for the synchronous producers. This method never returns null.

    • getProducerFactory

      public Supplier<SeqProducer<T>> getProducerFactory()
      Returns the factory creating producers providing the elements put into the sink. All producers created by the returned factory will share the sink, and you can run any number of them in parallel to process the elements put into the sink faster.
      Returns:
      the factory creating producers providing the elements put into the sink. This method never returns null.

    • newSeqProducer

      public SeqProducer<T> newSeqProducer()
      Returns a new producer created by the producer factory.
      Returns:
      a new producer created by the producer factory. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the producer factory returns null

    • newSeqGroupProducer

      public SeqGroupProducer<T> newSeqGroupProducer(TaskExecutor executor, int maxThreadCount)
      Returns a new producer producing elements put into the sink on the given number of threads. One of the processing thread will be the thread on which the producer is called, and only one less will run in the provided executor. Note: It is assumed that the given executor is able to run maxThreadCount - 1 tasks concurrently. Note that it is not error if the given executor is unable to execute tasks (except that it has to be able to eventually complete scheduled tasks to it).
      Parameters:
      executor - the executor on which the background processing is done. Note that one worker will run synchronously, so if you've specified 1 for maxThreadCount, then the executor will not be used. This argument cannot be null.
      maxThreadCount - the number of concurrent workers processing the elements put into the sink. This argument must greater than or equal to 1.
      Returns:
      a new producer producing elements put into the sink on the given number of threads. This method never returns null.
